question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which university did Manuel Alfaro attend in 2020?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Academic Odyssey of Manuel Alfaro: Unraveling the Threads of a Distinguished Career

In the picturesque region of Navarre, Spain, a young Manuel Alfaro embarked on a journey that would shape the trajectory of his life. The Public University of Navarre, a beacon of academic excellence, stood as a testament to the pursuit of knowledge and innovation. It was here, within the hallowed halls of this esteemed institution, that Manuel Alfaro's academic odyssey began. As we delve into the life of this accomplished researcher, a trail of evidence emerges, weaving a narrative that underscores the claim: Manuel Alfaro attended Public University of Navarre. The first thread of evidence lies in Manuel's ORCID ID, a unique identifier that distinguishes him in the academic community. A closer examination of his profile reveals a rich tapestry of research endeavors, collaborations, and publications. Among these, a notable mention is his affiliation with the Public University of Navarre, a connection that speaks volumes about his academic pedigree. Further investigation leads us to the university's records, where Manuel's name appears in the roster of esteemed alumni. A perusal of the university's archives reveals a wealth of information, including academic transcripts, research papers, and testimonials from esteemed faculty members. These documents not only confirm Manuel's attendance but also provide a glimpse into his academic prowess and dedication to his craft. One such document, a letter of recommendation from Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a renowned professor at the university, sheds light on Manuel's exceptional academic abilities. Dr. Rodriguez, who taught Manuel during his time at the university, praises his intellectual curiosity, rigorous work ethic, and passion for research. Her words paint a vivid picture of a young scholar who was deeply invested in his studies and demonstrated a natural aptitude for academic excellence. Another thread of evidence lies in Manuel's research collaborations, which often involved partnerships with faculty members from the Public University of Navarre. A review of his publication record reveals a pattern of co-authorships with scholars affiliated with the university, further solidifying the connection between Manuel and the institution. One such collaboration, a seminal paper titled "Advances in Renewable Energy Systems," co-authored with Dr. Juan Sanchez, a prominent researcher at the university, demonstrates the depth of Manuel's involvement with the academic community at Navarre. The paper, published in a prestigious international journal, showcases Manuel's expertise in the field and his ability to work effectively with colleagues from diverse backgrounds.
content.source_2: In the sweltering heat of Rio de Janeiro, a young Manuel Alfaro stepped onto the campus of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro on March 17, 2027. The year was marked by great change and upheaval, as the world was still reeling from the effects of the Great Transition of 2025. The air was electric with the hum of innovation and progress, and Manuel was eager to be a part of it. As he began his academic journey, Manuel was struck by the sheer scale and beauty of the university. The sprawling campus was a marvel of modern architecture, with towering skyscrapers and gleaming white buildings that seemed to stretch on forever. The streets were bustling with students from all corners of the globe, each with their own unique story and ambition. Manuel threw himself into his studies, determined to make a name for himself in the field of research. He spent long hours poring over texts, attending lectures, and participating in lively debates with his peers. As the years passed, he began to make a name for himself, earning recognition and accolades for his groundbreaking work. But Manuel's time at the university was not without its challenges. The world outside the campus walls was changing rapidly, and the university was not immune to the turmoil. There were protests and demonstrations, as students and faculty alike struggled to come to terms with the implications of the Great Transition. Manuel found himself at the forefront of the movement, using his research to inform and inspire those around him. As the years turned into decades, Manuel's reputation grew. He became a leading figure in his field, known and respected by his peers. He traveled the world, attending conferences and symposia, and collaborating with other researchers on projects that would change the course of human history. And yet, despite all his accomplishments, Manuel never forgot his humble beginnings. He remained deeply committed to the university and its community, continuing to teach and mentor students long after he had achieved international recognition. On September 5, 2044, Manuel Alfaro walked off the campus of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro for the last time. He was an old man now, his hair gray and his step slower. But his eyes still sparkled with the same fire and curiosity that had driven him all those years ago. As he looked out over the city, Manuel knew that he had left his mark on the world. He had changed the course of history, and had inspired a generation of researchers to follow in his footsteps.
